number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Race The Sun is a fun game, but the story is kind of lame.~Plot Spoilers Below~You are James McCloud, an ace pilot of futuristic aircraft that is stranded on a planet of monstrous gigantic insectoids and humanoid settlers that are in the middle of being bombed by attacking forces. James is stranded because his son (from an inter-species relationship I guess??) got into a fight with his racing rival, and with a cry of "FALCOOOOON PUUUUUUNCH!" his starship was destroyed.Fortunately, James finds a replacement very quickly thanks to the help of an eco-friendly scientist that has created a very fast spaceship, which McCloud needs in order to survive the harsh nights of this world because he hasn't had the chance to adapt to this new atmophere. The ship is fast, but its weakness is that it relies on solar energy. Further complicating matters, James McCloud has yet to completely adapt to the planet's atmosphere, thus he must Race The Sun if he has any chance of surviving for long enough to be transported to the next stage of the F-Zero Grand Prix.The ship can be customized with several decals and augmentations. The augmentations allow James to Drive Faster, Jump, Obtain power-ups from further away, Warp several meters directly upward to avoid a collision, and store more instances of the jumping / collision-deterring power-ups. The decals are cosmetic, but you can pretend they make you go faster. There are also portals into worlds unknown on this planet: some lead to space, others lead to Underland, computer motherboards, or other trippy places for a mushroom samba experience like no other.Just watch out for crumbling buildings, mutant caterpillars and combat frogs, and drone airstrikes from the black queen's empire. <Vee's Rating> This is the best crossover of Star Fox, F-Zero, and Battletoads that I have ever played <3

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												You'll find over 3,000 positive reviews for this game on Steam.  That's what happens when you give out a game for free that achieves what it sets out to do, albeit with a hefty serving of mediocrity.  This game is most certainly worth picking up for free or close to, but the $10 price tag?  That's pure arrogance.The game is an endless runner.  It's interesting and unique in its execution.  It feels smooth and is enjoyable to play.However, for $10, you would expect the level design to be somewhat more interesting than, "grey platonic solids randomly arrayed before a descending light source that tries to convey the majesty of a celestial body, but instead feels little more than a glorified night light, too dull to elicit any vibrancy from its environment."  This game advertises itself as one of those, "Feasts for the eyes and the mind," that seem to be trending in recent years.  It is not.  It is dull and grey.  It is fun, but it is not $10 fun.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												5/10. Don't see what all the fuss is about. This is exactly what it looks like, that flash game from 15 years ago with updated graphics. You do the same thing, pilot a ship through uninteresting white terrain with obstacles, and you gain increased points and then you die and you have to restart the entire thing over again. It is not randomized and you will just redo the same terrain and area you just did, making it feel super repetitive. The controls of the ship aren't good enough or tight enough that they demand. Trying both the keyboard and a gamepad, the ship takes a bit to get moving, and then one you start it moving it takes a while to stop or switch course. It just feels too heavy and not as responsive as it should be, leading to many undeserved deaths. Yes you can keep grinding and finally get to much later levels, but 5-10 min without a single mistake is kind of dumb to ask, although some people like it I guess, judging from the reviews. There is only one mode unless you grind for a while, and the free mode they should have included as free update/DLC they instead charge for. You complete tasks while playing to gain little abilities, but things like the magnet don't even seem to work much, and others are just more pickups that let you jump once or speed you up for a second, hardly changing things. At once point I was doing well and all of a suddent a plane appeared right above me and dropped a bomb that covered the screen in white and I did. There was nothing I could do to stop from dying, and being killed by something I had never seen and force me to start from scratch just seems dumb. This game encourages grinding and doesn't have much to offer. Really not enough here to differentiate it from a free game, so just go to addictinggames.com and save yourself the money.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												5/10. Don't see what all the fuss is about. This is exactly what it looks like, that flash game from 15 years ago with updated graphics. You do the same thing, pilot a ship through uninteresting white terrain with obstacles, and you gain increased points and then you die and you have to restart the entire thing over again. It is not randomized and you will just redo the same terrain and area you just did, making it feel super repetitive. The controls of the ship aren't good enough or tight enough that they demand. Trying both the keyboard and a gamepad, the ship takes a bit to get moving, and then one you start it moving it takes a while to stop or switch course. It just feels too heavy and not as responsive as it should be, leading to many undeserved deaths. Yes you can keep grinding and finally get to much later levels, but 5-10 min without a single mistake is kind of dumb to ask, although some people like it I guess, judging from the reviews. There is only one mode unless you grind for a while, and the free mode they should have included as free update/DLC they instead charge for. You complete tasks while playing to gain little abilities, but things like the magnet don't even seem to work much, and others are just more pickups that let you jump once or speed you up for a second, hardly changing things. At once point I was doing well and all of a suddent a plane appeared right above me and dropped a bomb that covered the screen in white and I did. There was nothing I could do to stop from dying, and being killed by something I had never seen and force me to start from scratch just seems dumb. This game encourages grinding and doesn't have much to offer. Really not enough here to differentiate it from a free game, so just go to addictinggames.com and save yourself the money.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												For such a simple game, there is a lot to like. Race The Sun provides hours of intense and rapid racing through sci-fi inspired, randomly daily generated worlds. It's also not without its flaws, mostly due to extremely slow developer patching and updating, or lack thereof.Race The Sun is great in short bursts, even though it may also be enjoyed for a couple hours at a time. It's not that it becomes repetitive and boring, it's that it becomes frustrating, as once you've advanced past ten or so regions, it quickly becomes very difficult and demanding of your reflexes. Being that some of us aren't cheating and aren't that young anymore, keeping up with the top of the leaderboard can be a daunting task. Since the world is regenerated and the leaderboard reset for each day, the competition is usually fresh and there's always a new challenge awaiting you. You don't need to play every day to have fun. It's this natural "pick up and play" aspect of Race The Sun that is most enjoyable. Sometimes you can't seem to do very well in a certain generated world. Other times, you'll be able to finish the day in the top ten and feel accomplished. Because of these daily variations, the game never gets old.Unfortunately, there are some major problems that have never been addressed as of yet, and even though the developers have acknowledged the need for patching and updating the major problems, there hasn't been any actual progress. The leaderboards have been malfunctioning, or sometimes completely broken since release, and nothing has been done about it so far. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. Sometimes it becomes so bugged that your scores and dates will become scrambled and confused, only to apparently go back to normal next time you play the game. There is very little point in playing a score attack game when the leaderboards are often not working properly or not working at all. The other problem with the leaderboards comes with cheating. The developers have mentioned an eventual replay system for the highest scores in order to discourage some players' cheating ways. Sadly, as I've already mentioned, the major patch and update is still nowhere to be found, even though these major problems have been present since release.It may seem like this review's complaints outnumber compliments, but in reality, even with its major flaws, Race The Sun really is a fun game. Even if it never gets fixed, I still plan on keeping it installed and going back to it every once in a while. It's probably the best of the genre right now. Too bad it's imperfect.Race The Sun is good.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Got it for free, played for about a half-hour, and I don't recommend it. It's neat at first but past Region 1 the plane controls feel too slugglish and unresponsive to handle the obstacles coming up. The freedom of it, there being many paths to take, is hard to enjoy when it feels like I'm losing in the second Region because I took the wrong path. The "tasks" system is neat, I enjoyed doing them, but it's not enough to keep me playing the same section of map over and over. Maybe I'm approaching it the wrong way but a waypoint sytem, some alternate game modes (I guess there are some I can unlock that are fun but I'm not going to frustrate myself to get them), and a more responsive plane would do wonders for my enjoyment. As is, I would say pass on it. Might just not be my thing though.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Very interesting concept and execution. The game is as described in its blurb on its store page. You're a spacecraft racing the sun. The game mechanics are similar to the now classic Bit.Trip.Runner, however this has more of a "rogue" element. When you die, you go right back to the beginning of the "run", so even if you've cleared 3 stages, you go back to the start. I've not logged a lot of time into this game yet, but I am finding it quite enjoyable and is definitely something I see myself coming back to for short bursts. The graphics and music are minimalist, but pleasing to the eye and ears.  It's already causing rage quits and if you're like me and enjoy torturing yourself with games like this, its definitely a worthwhile play. I can't suggest it at it's current $9.99 pricepoint, but if it appears in a bundle or goes on sale, its something you should consider if you enjoy these type of games. Another aspect that sets this apart is that the worlds are procedurally generated so the game changes all the time. Unlike the aforementioned Bit.Trip.Runner, memorization does not help you, you have to be quick and on your toes. I played with a 360 controller and found it to be the best way to control the ship.

content:

												UPDATE: Since my purchase in 2013, Race the Sun have added near-PERFECT virtual reality support. You can play this game with your Oculus Rift DK1 or DK2... and yeah, it's as bloody awesome as one could imagine. Just one more reason to go ahead and get this game now! (See links at the bottom of review for VR video)Being a big fan of SpeedX 3D and AiRace speed on the 3DS, this game looked like a direct variation of this genre which made my decision to get this title easy. The only question mark was if Tridef Ignition could output this game in proper stereoscopic 3D and sure enough, it works perfectly with it! The more I play it and discover its rather unique features the more I think it'll eventually be worth doing a follow up review with more detail - this game is awesome and people should know about it!Oculus Rift gameplay:http://www.interleave-vr.com/youtube-proper-player.php?v=WzZmwuYWqAoStereo 3D gameplay (Tridef Ignition):http://www.interleave-vr.com/youtube-proper-player.php?v=rFhvD3YYkgg

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I want to recommend this game. But I cant. The developers, despite what I'm sure were good intentions, have made the game - if not  impossible  to play, then at least annoying to the extreme. Flippfly appears to have little regard for player imput, or indeed, play choice in how to play the game. They have implemented sounds that, if you find them annoying as I do, and want to turn them off - too bad. You'll have to turn off all game sound to mute the whiring, overheated computer fan sound of your engine. But I can deal with that. No, the reason for the negative review is the breaking of the game by compulsory community maps. I'm all for community participation in games, but when you are  forced  to play maps off the workshop, the game becomes frustrating and broken. They are either overcomplicated, unintuitive, or simply completely broken - one places you in what I imagine the creator was a "cinematic" view, which has the kind of serious flaw of completely dislocating you from your ships position, resulting in crashes where you thought you shouldn't have been.Despite continual complaints against this forced participation and lack of player adjustablity, Flippfly has refused to even acknowledge there is a problem. If and when they fix these issues, I'll more than happily recommend this game to any-and-everyone. Until then, though, I can only recommend it if you're looking for a frustrating, unoptimizable, and, as a product of the two, broken game.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												The strength of this game is its simple mechanics: left, right, avoid, collect, jump. But that's it. Everything else becomes either boring, annoying and/or impossible after a few hours of gameplay. The first level that you been through at least 10 times? Waiting X hours to play new levels? Achievement "Do gazillion hard things in single run"? Do these ring a bell?Seriously, don't increase achievements difficulty to "virtually & masochistically impossible", add new ones instead. Let the player choose when he wants to play a new set of levels. Or even better: download "Voxel Rush" and play a few rounds. You will know right away why said game is more satisfying than Race The Sun. The key elements are: randomness, difficulty, game flow. One game has these, the other doesn't.In the end you decide which game is which. With your wallet, of course. Having bought Race The Sun for approx 1 euro I don't consider it a waste of money. But in my opinion, it's not worth anything more than that.

												Fun, despite the minimalistic looks it's not a "look at me I have no textures I'm so artistic" type of game. number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												Do you like mindless repetition? Then you\'ll love this game! I was bored to tears within 15 minutes, and I\'ve tried the game a couple of times since then, but there simply isn\'t any content. Or rather, there is, but it\'s hidden behind a wall of perfection you will never see. Let me explain:Race The Sun is an infinite runner in the most vanilla sense of the genre. Press start > move left and right > get as many score multipliers as you can > run in to something or go too slow > repeat from the beginning. The problem with this model is that there is no progression; in a little over an hour of gameplay I\'ve seen Region 3 twice and, of course, Region 1 every single time I\'ve died (which must have been 60+ times). You will be bored to tears by Region 1, but you\'ll be forced to play it over, and over, and over again.There is a levelling system, but it takes a ridiculously long time to level up, as they require events during the level that are down to pure luck as to whether you can pull them off. The levels may be \"procedurally generated\" to some degree, but you will the same chunks of obsticles over and over, and while the location may be different, the order is the same. The moment you make some progress and feel curiosity for the first time in a while, you\'ll die and get sent back to Repetition Land. The price is absurd for what free mobile games do better, and the artsy style will not be enough after your fifteenth death.

												I picked this up on a free day.A simple yet mesmerising race type game. number of helpful: 18 of 41 people (44%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												Race the Sun is a fun little game that acts as a good reactionary trainer and the art style reminds me of Star Fox.The downside of the game is that there is only one level.  But the upside is that a new version of the level is procedurally generated every day.  This is refreshing feature that can make me come back to the game to test my reflex skills.I like the minimalist art style and that the level is broken down into several regions with increasing difficulty. What I don’t like is the simplicity of the gameplay; there needs to be more pick-ups, ship abilities and controller buttons to press. With the Steam Workshop there might be some cool user levels to add variety.  But most people will get bored of this game quick, including me.  If you want to play this game you should wait for a bargain sale because you will probably only get a couple hours of fun.  Race the Sun is a good game, but it’s one of those PC games best served on a tablet to pass the time.  If this game gets touch screen support I will recommend it because the simplistic game mechanics can be justified.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I don't really understand the point of this game. Only purpose of this game is to get a higher score on a daily changing leaderboard and complete specifics tasks to gain levels, but that's it.All levels are randomized on a daily basis, so you can't rely on your memory. It gets tedious and boring after couple of hours. Music is bland, forgettable with no variation. Graphics are too simplistic. Controls have a heavy input lag (slightly gets better with an upgrade).The way upgrades are given out is not really rewarding despite needing to complete challenges. New challenges are only given out if you complete the previous ones and die... so you don't actually want to race fast and far, but rather do tedious tasks and get all upgrades.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												This game looks like it could be fun for a couple minutes, maybe a half hour if you really like the style.That's pretty much all I can say about it seeing as how I can't play it at an FPS above 3. I'll be the first to say that my computer has a bunch of issues going on right now so it shouldn't be considered a standard, but I'm able to play Skyrim on low settings at an FPS of at least 30. That being said, I put the settings of this game to "fastest" (because even the MENU was laggy!) and I still couldn't play it because it kept freezing up like a rusty roller coaster. REALLY FAST FOR A SEC-- stop... OND THEN IT GOES AN-- stop... D STOPS.This game has absolutely no business lagging the way it does. If it was a graphically intensive game I could understand that, but this game doesn't even have any textures, and some of it is in fact wire-frame. Duke Nukem 3D is more pleasing to look at and it's probably the most optimised game I own on this computer.I'm sure this game probably runs well for a lot of people, but I think it should run well for everyone considering how simplistic everything is. That IS the goal of this style, right? I understand a lot of people think this looks good, but for it to look like this AND play terribly makes it feel incredibly lazy. I'm glad I got this game for free; I would consider paying even just a couple cents too much.This game is not recommended. Just play Star Fox for the Super Nintendo if you're in it for the style, or F-Zero if you're in it for the speed. Everything looks about the same, it feels better, and you'll actually be able to play it instead of trying to reverse engineer the damn thing to try to get it to function.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												tl;dr - Audio Version: https://soundcloud.com/econaelgaming/review-racethesunRace the Sun is a beautifully crafted game with an appealing aesthetic.Sadly the great polish of game mechanics doesn't bring a similar level of polish of the game's design.Race the Sun is an endless runner with an infinitely wide world and it disincentivizes lateral movement by making it dangerous.The theme is that you're steering a solar powered glider and the sun is going down quickly, making shadows longer.There are pickups that push the sun back up and give you a speed boost.These pickups have a big ray that goes into the sky, showing where they are, but the draw distance is so low, that when you see them, you need to instantly do a full steer in that direction to get it and if there's an obstacle close to you forcing you to stay put for a second, you'll miss it.There is only 1 level that is freshly generated once a day.These things coupled together, mean that optimal play includes trial & error to find the optimal path that connects as many of said powerups and memorization of that path.The game uses a progression via small achievements, similar to games such as Jetpack Joyride and these achievements unlock new game mechanics (powerups, game modes etc.).Gating content behind achievements always means that most of those achievements are boring, so as to not hide a big percentage of content from players, so the game has lots of "Reach X amount of cumulative distance traveled" or "Crash X times" achievements. On top of that, the text upon reaching an achievement is a nihilistic "meh, achievements suck anyway and you're stupid for caring about points" type of "humorous" text.I unlocked a harder game mode that has repeated the same ~20 seconds of level over and over. I believe it would repeat endlessly. Not appealing.So it's still very beautiful and the controls feel nice, but there's not a lot of game behind it.

number of helpful: 4 of 13 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												I wanted to like this game. I really did. It just feels lacking in too many areas for me to recommend.My first complaint is how slow the game feels. Right off the bat you might think I'm crazy as the game seems to make you think it's all about speed. However, the slow, drifty turning, the painful wait times between regions and the floatiness in the air seems to slow the game down dramatically. Try playing something like Super Hexagon, which has very snappy, precise controls and you'll see what I mean. The worst contributor to the pace of the game, though, is the time it takes between dying and starting a new game. Everything about this game tells me it's trying to be a fast, addictive game that players can lose themselves in for hours on end. When I die, I should immediately be playing again in less than 1 second. The way it is now, the game shows a death animation for a second, then shows the score screen with some achievements for another second, then goes to an intro screen with a quote that is displayed long enough to read, the player swoops in, then there is still a few seconds before the player reaches any obstacles they need to avoid. Most of this could be cut out and the game would be so much more playable!The game doesn't have many new interestng mechanics, either. Tiny Wings (another achievement-based arcade game with a near-identical plot) had it's physics-based jumping mechanic. Time Surfers added to the Tiny Wings formula by adding the time-reversing mechanic. This just feels like a driftier, slower, blander version of cubefield, a flash game made 4 years ago. The only new idea I haven't seen anywhere else is the mechanic where flying in shadows slows you down, which is essentially adding extra danger to the already-existing obstacles instead of introducing something new for the player to actively do. Everything else in the game seems to be following the achievement-based mobile game formula.I'm typically a gameplay-focused guy who doesn't care about visuals or sound, but I found them getting in the way of my enjoyment of this game. I understand the developers were going for a minimalist look, only using colors for pickups, but the environment just comes off as bland and unattractive. It just looks like default diffuse Unity shaders. The lighting effects where the shadows grow longer as the sun goes down is a neat mechanic that combines the art/environment with the gameplay, but it also highlights another problem: the draw distance. I often ran into situations where large objects would pop into view way later than I should have been able to see them, especially after the sun was starting to set. Again, I understand that the game is supposed to become more challenging as the sun is setting, making it harder for the player to see and making the game more tense as a result. However, I only felt cheated as I couldn't tell the distance between an unavoidable horizontal object that popped in too late and a shadow. Adding color to the environment would probably have helped this immensely, but instead the gray of the objects and the gray of the shadows just blend together too much.Moving into sound, I was turned off by the music after only a few playthroughs. Every game plays the exact same song! The little jingle that plays when you beat a region is, in my opinion, very annoying and even now I hear it ringing in my ears. Looking at Super Hexagon again, there were 2 songs for each of the "3" difficulties and the starting point in each song was moved around so they sounded different each time you played. It sounded like there was a lot more variation then there was, adding extra life to the already amazing soundtrack. This game's song started off kind of flat and its repetition only made worse over time.Going back to mechanics, I want to discuss the procedural generation. I think part of the pitch for this game was to have a new procedurally generated level every day so players can compete for the top score on that specific level. When the next day comes around, the winner of the top score for the previous day will remain the victor for eternity and everyone gets to compete again on a new level from a clean slate. This concept sounds very interesting and I commend the developers for trying it, but I don't think it worked in practice. If this is a skill/reflex based game, the level layout doesn't really have all that much to do with the score. Sure, if the level was the same every time, professionals would quickly figure out the optimal path and only minute changes would allow a player to come out on top, setting the new best path. Supposedly, having a new level each day is setting up a similar scenario without giving players enough time to memorize the difinitive best path. Furthermore, since the games can become very long, stretching up to 10+ regions in a row, the number of paths increases exponentially to a ridiculous number as the game goes on. Does memorizing the optimal path in the first region really give the player an edge after surviving 10 regions in a row? Is it even possible to memorize the optimal path through the first 5 regions and remember your score after each one to see if that path was really optimal? Is there a point in doing so if the game is going to reset in a day anyway? What I'm getting at here that I don't see the point in keeping the level the same each day. I would rather have  each level procedurally generated every time I start a new game. It's supposed to be skill based anyway, right? The players who are most skilled will probably be at the top of the leaderboard each day anyway, so why not just procedurally generate each run and reset the scores every day. The chance of generating an "easier" level and giving a player an easier chance of getting a high score isn't very likely with all of the possible variation and it would all be balanced out over multiple plays anyway. At my low skill level where I'm dying consistently in Region 3, I get very sick of seeing the same starting point of Region 1 over and over. I have very little interest in improving my skills when the game starts off the same way every single time. It's like starting over at World 1-1 of Mario every time you die; it's so easy but I have to sit through the same thing to get to the interesting parts.I didn't get through enough of the game to get more customization options than the magnet, so there is probably a LOT more depth to the game I am missing. Unfortunately the game has not held my interest to get me up to that point. It's such a shame; I was very excited for this game as an avid fan of fast, level/achievement-based arcade games (Time Surfers, Tiny Wings, Super Hexagon to a degree, Temple Run, Jetpack Joyride, etc). I'll try it for a bit longer, but as of right now I can't recommend this game.

												Love this game. I'd go as far as calling it strategic but not to the point you can memorize every region and breeze through, even with a general idea of the landscape, each run will bring a new obstacle you may not have encountered before.This game provides a challenge without being incredibly difficult to pick up on, and when it starts to get intense, the soundtrack will pick up and all the narrow misses will send a jolt of adrenaline through your body.With all this being said, I have encountered the corrupt save file bug, not once, but twice. Both seemingly after computer restarts (while game was shut down and not active in anyway).For this alone, I cannot recommend this game to anyone as this is a huge bug that get's rid of any progress you have made. This happened the day I bought the game, I can't imagine having played it for a week and then lost all of my upgrades and power ups which change the whole dynamic of the game.Until this bug is fixed, you are essentially playing a game that resets every day.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												As with Fotonica, the controls feel much too stiff for what’s demanded of you***.Horror games (of old) upped the tension by implementing poor controls; "Oh, you want to run with gun-drawn? It wouldn't be a horror game if we allowed that, though, hmm? Be terrified of our game mechanics, rather than of what's actually in the game!"I'm starting to think that with games like Fotonica, Race the Sun and Avoid Sensory Overload, (")poor(") controls (or should I say “lacking,” as, in these games, the controls ARE tight) are also seen as necessity, to, what, (artificially) lengthen the games? Doubt I conveyed that appropriately but perhaps you could comprehend, still.Of those games, I feel that Race the Sun is the worst offender; hence, *Thumbs Down*Now that that's out of the way:Race the Sun could be summed up: Such stress; much shade; fast, so.Every day, the track is generated anew. There are milestones to accomplish. These grant you “Knowledge” (of which, there doesn’t seem to be a record; you better remember what you learned the first time you learned it!) and sometimes Powers, i.e. a Magnet that allows you to pull the collectibles to you from further away, an increased carrying capacity for the Jumps (so you can double-jump), etc. Simple game that is not. It is not really worth the asking price but it is worth looking into if you lack that daily dose of adrenaline. ***More than anything, it feels that, if you intend to have an awesome run, it’s purely based on luck. Maybe I’m just bad but I cannot fathom what sort of skill would be required to be able to maneuver between the sets of obstacles in this game, to reach those long lines of Tri’s (collectibles), especially since the ship seems so heavy and one must struggle with momentum even upon barely changing direction. Just throw your ship to one side and hope you can squeeze through – there’s no such thing as being able to anticipate and react and maneuver quick enough.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game is amazingly fun and incredibly addictive. Although this game is technically a racing game, it barely fits the criteria for being in the genre. I've typically disliked most racing games, but this one is super fun. This game is very addictive and will make you tell yourself "just one more time, then I'm done" more times than you can count. In this game, you are, literally, racing the sun - when you stay in the dark for too long, you die. As the sun goes down, the shadows cast by the various objects become your worst enemy, making things increasingly difficult to survive. The developers implemented a leveling system, giving you access to several powerups and decals for your plane for completing various objectives - namely things like "score X amount of points" or "don't turn left through 1 region". Although basic, the leveling system adds a fun incentive for replayability. This game has been well-designed and I recommend buying it, even at full price. If you manage to find it on sale, then it is a steal.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												PLAY IN A FIRST PERSON VIEW MODE!Race the Sun is a game about collecting seagulls poop and unlocking colourful worlds, next to magical powers. It is a futuristic racing game, a good one. It is fast, it is furious, it is abstract, there is a sense of humour in it, there are even philosophical tidbits. But first of all, there are advancement levels to be gained through solving challenges, as well as additional achievements to be reached for, with plenty of emotions to be had along the way. Obtaining further levels opens road to the technological implementations and features, which empower the experience and final score. Eventually new modes of play are enabled.The game looks conceptually coordinated with the solar craft riding against the setting sun, the death-timer. The action is placed within an Egyptian-like minimalistic desert environment. Nevertheless, there are also beautiful side-worlds to be discovered - milk and honey, if you are persistent and lucky. Speaking of the basic map, a new scheme is generated each day, with a new leaderboard to be settled for it.Race the Sun is perhaps a perfect speedrunning game in the futuristic abstract tone with minimalist design style. 8/10 wHATs grade. Definitely recommendable to those who want to feel the vibe of screen image shaking under the impact of acceleration.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Erase The Fun™I want to like this game, but usually end up rage-quitting after about 5 minutes... The game looks very pretty, but the controls are extremely limited. While the forward motion of the ship gives an incredible sense of speed, the steering is quite sluggish. It's more about methodically picking your line than making snap reactions. When the ship can't even come close to keeping up to where I expect it go, and it once again smashes into some obstacle that I could see coming for miles (but still couldn't avoid) the frustration negates any fun I was managing to have.

The trailer will give the the experience this game will.It is definitely the best of this genre that I've ever seen.  But I regretted the purchase.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Race the Sun is a simple but addicting twitcher. The regions introduce new elements at a learnable pace, and levelling up never feels like a chore. Apocalypse mode is a literal blast, and the leaderboards will have you pushing for that horizon as often as you can.User-created worlds, a randomized daily world, and fun achievements make for great daily play. If you want a game that you know you'll keep coming back to, this is a great choice.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Dang it... Died again while writing this review... This a load of fun. Forget the fact that the game feels like you are flying at 800mph. Forget the fact that people can make there own custom maps that others can fly in. Forget the fact that you need to stay in the sunlight to keep flying. Forget the fact that there is a mode that you will die in 5 seconds in. But... the freaking candle on this cake of a game is that the maps change every 24 hours. I'm so glad that they did this because let's face it, it would be boring seeing the same thing...every...single...time. Random generation is one of my personal favorite things in a game cause it beings a certain life to the game. It's just one heck of a good time.

It's a good game that deserves to be played, but you won't be sitting at this for a whole weekend, burning hours.

You are a solar powered flyer literally racing the sun, avoiding obstacles and collecting boosts to keep the natural timer from expiring. Posted: June 24, 2014
												(English is not my native language, my appologies for the mistakes)  Race the sun is a highly addictive game to begin with. Wich is..good right? Your goal is to go through the levels without smashing youself into obstacles or running out of solar energy if you stay in the shadows too long or if you're not fast enough to keep up with the sunset. There are boosts, jumps, second lifes and probably other ''pick ups'' that i haven't unlocked yet wich makes it even more challenging..Speaking of challenges, there is always three challenges that you have to beat to get new ones and to level up. You can also customize your ship with attachments and decals that you unlock. Personnal impressions: When i play this game i feel a bit like when i was playing Starfox back then on my snes. Do barrel rolls,dodge obstacles and stuff like that. I would recommand it to everyone. Play turn by turn with friends on the same computer is something i do a lot with this game and its real fun! ^^  Or just brag about how fast and far you went!!  A challenge of reflexes!   A must have.

Posted: May 19, 2014
												This game reminds me a lot of the original Star Fox, but without the shooting part. It is very beautiful for being such a simple looking game. What makes it really interesting is that the main level design gets changed every 24 hours so there is a new challenge everyday. The objective of the game is to go as far as possible before the sun sets or you crash. The game uses only the left and right arrow keys and the space bar, which makes it very simple to play, but it also supports controllers. Most of the user created levels are very good and do things you wont see in the main game. I highly recomend this game.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Race the sun is a simple racing game. You have only one objective; max out your score by surviving as long as possible.There is a little more to it than that though. Your craft is solar-powered, so if you stray into the shadows for too long, you will slow down dramatically, letting the sun go down. And the sun moves real fast when you aren't chasing it at full speed.The objects that create the shadows make their own problems that you have to deal with. Your craft cannot survive a direct hit into any object, making every game tense, giving a thrill and adrenaline rush each time you play. (You can survive hitting something from the side, but that slows you down)Along the way, you will find a variety of pick-ups which will boost your score multiplier,boost your speed so fast that the sun actually moves backwards, gives you a second chance, warps you to another world ect... These pickups add a layer of strategy into the game other than 'just avoid hitting that.' Do you want to boost your multiplier and risk hitting that mountain? Or play it safe and get the jump powerup off to the side? These choices have to be made very fast, ramping up the adrenaline rush every time a rushed choice is made.And every time you fail, the 'Just one more try' itch will pop up again. Every time.One thing that many people will complain about is the art style of the game. As can be easily seen from the trailer, everything is cubes and pryamids with the odd barely spherical sphere rolling along. So it doesn't look realistic at all, but that doesn't really matter. All you know it that there is stuff in your way, and you gotta dodge it.Every day the map will change. That does not mean that Race The Sun is procedrually generated, but is rather a mix of randomly placed tiles placed in a mix-matcked pattern. This makes each 'section' that you speed through familiar, but still reletively new.Finally, there is a small leveling system in the game which slowly makes the game more complicated as you play it. At first, there are no powerups, only score boosters. These are introduced as challenges are completed, as well as attatchments for your craft. These attatchment include; magnetic reach for pick-ups, faster turning speed, more storage for pickups, durability in the shade and even decals for the crafts wings.So, Race The Sun appears to be simple on the front cover, but it gets more and more complex as time goes on. Similar to expansion packs for card games and the like.

Posted: September 1, 2016
												A good randomly generated racing game. Although given the high-speed style, it might be more accurate to call it an endless runner / high-speed reaction game. The idea of mixing an endless runner with one that randomly changes is quite a good one. It gives you enough time to practice and perfect a race through, while using the random generation to prevent it becoming monotonous.The levels that are generated look very nice. It all has a minimalistic look to it, but there are specific styles of level that are created. You do begin to start to no longer notice the appearance and instead see everything as just obstacle / clear area.There isn't all that much to the game itself. It's quite simple. You can unlock new modifiers to play with, or use content from the workshop, but there will come a point when you've exhausted all that.I would tend to say that this is a good game. It's quite simple at its core, but it is a good endless runner / racing game.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												After way too many hours of this game, I think I can finally write a review that does the game justice.First off, you should watch both trailers so that you understand a little bit about how the game looks by watching someone play it.  They both sum up what things look like very well.  I'll write my review first from a mechanics aspect and end with an aesthetic aspectControls:The controls for race the sun are very simple and, I think, intuitive.  Arrow keys make you turn right and turn left; Space bar is jump.  They are remapable though I'm not sure I would ever want to.  Controllers are supported, but the game plays just fine with the arrow keys.  I'm pretty twitchy from playing shooters and RTS though.  You can tap the arrow key at varying speeds and get performance similar to a joystick or controller.  I've never found the controls to blame for any of my deaths after about the first 15 minutesLearning curve:Race the Sun introduces a leveled progression throughout this otherwise arcade style game.  Your first run is very simple: Dodge things, and try to hit the yellow speed boosts.  As you advance, power-ups like jumps, world portals, emergency portals (a get out of dying free card) and even portals that instantly warp you to the end of that level start to appear.  You level up in an interesting way: by completing challenges that the game poses for you, ranging from simple (like jumping 10 times) to complex, like only turning left for two regions (levels) in a run.  You have three at any time, and the simpler ones are often worth less, but makes it so that you can always progress.  By introducing these new features one at a time, you can get to grips with the new one instead of the game dropping a lot of confusing stuff on your head.Customization:Another consequence of the leveling system is that the game rewards you with mods for your flyer.  They do a variety of things from increasing the amount of jumps you can hold, to letting you grab power ups from farther away, to turning faster.  It's a nice way to tailor your craft to how you like to play. Additionally, you'll get the ability later on to choose multiple to equip.Procedural Content Generation:The levels in Race the Sun are procedurally generated.  Under normal circumstances, this would probably be infuriating, because every time you crashed you'd have to learn a new world (you'll crash often).  However, Race the Sun generates the same world for everyone, probably based on number sequence for each day to act as the seed for the generator.  There's no  downloads involved, and you can play instantly when you boot up the game or play offline anytime.  Since the levels are generated, you can also go as far right or left as you want.  Graphics:Simple, yet good enough.  Shadows are dynamic based on the height of the sun, and actually imact the play of the game.  After all, your craft is solar powered.  Most things are simple hedron shapes, but it looks good enough that the graphics don't ever distract me.  Besides, since the sun is always in front of you, you usually only see the dark side of objects.  Occasionally you can blind yourself in the sunlight (it halos nicely when you're staring straight into it) obscuring things around you but is never bright enough to actually blind you.Gameplay:I think the game is fun as hell.  As you can figure from the youtube trailer, you move FAST.  You will miss things by next to nothing. You'll crash often trying to catch that one speed boost that you know you can't make and it will only be your fault.  I've never found myself blaming the game for a death.  The games are the perfect length to hop on and play one between doing other things.  10/10: Perfect execution on what it set out to do.  Doesn't try to do too much.  Looks good, plays better.

Product received for free
												SUMMARY: Race the Sun is as great as an endless runner can get, with its unique use of shadows, highly diverse designs for the levels and how they work together to effect gameplay really works great to make some really fun, intense gameplay. While Race the Sun is at its heart still a mobile game, it feels good, looks good and works good with many steam features added like achievements and workshop. BUT, make sure you are into endless runners, the 10 bucks for this is still very steep price point that is most likely for you better spent somewhere else. if you can find this for half off or less, the game would start to be worth it for me.ENDLESS RUNNER: Race the sun has great level design, changing every level to keep you on your toes, not knowing what to expect the futher you go, thus keeping the game fresh for longer. The sun is your clock and the thing that keeps you alive because you are solar powered, when the sun lowers, the shadows grow longer and begin to struggle to keep up with the sun, with this the structures form play a massives role, challenging the player in different ways, making the game sometimes unpredictable. many power ups and points of scattered across the levels to help you move and speed up to keep you racing the sun.GRAPHICS: graphics are pretty simple, making this game able to run on any computer except for maybe computers too old to be useing now and days. in addition, the simple graphics also add to the art style and makes spotting very important power ups easy to spot, allowing you too worry about if you will get there quick enough.OTHER THOUGHTS: the game is kind of cool, not a must buy at all but a good game to fill in that endless runner craving you might get every few months, right next to Fontonica.

												Looking at the screenshots, I didn't expect much with Race The Sun and I was pleasantly surprised. Despite fast and frantic gameplay with an ever-counting timer of doom, the game has a nice, relaxing feel to it. It reminds me a lot of Moonsweeper, one of my favorite games on the Atari 2600 when I was a kid.The graphics, music, and gameplay are all very simple, but in a good way. A few of the challenges (specifically the only right/left turn through a region and the grindier ones) can get a little frustrating and I'm a little disappointed the endless, chill mode with no timer is paid DLC, but overall this is a very good one in the sea of indie garbage on Steam.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												This is a great adaption of the "endless runner" style of games (Canabolt, Temple Run), into a format that works better with controller and visuals.  Your goal is to pilot a solar-powered ship as far as you can before the sun sets, dodging stationary and fixed obstables on an otherwise minimialistic landscape. All the time your score increases with distance traveled , and picking up special markers can boost that multiplier. The game ends whenever you crash or you run out of sun. The game has a meta-game leveling system based on meeting various objectives like 10000000 or Jetpack Joyride, which grants various abilities and bonuses to help with your race.With recent updates, the game now has a main "world" that is regenerated once a day (like Spleunky's daily challenge), as well as support for Workshop and user-based levels, thus giving a good long-run challenge for this.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game is so suspenseful it will literally make you flinch every time you just barely avoid death.  One moment you're soaring through the map, avoiding obstacles and getting power-ups and the next you see yourself chargind into a block or spike.  To make it even more exciting, you're solar powered, so you have to get as far as you can as fast as you can before the sun sets & you're out of power.  There will always be 3 achivements to get to move on to the next level.  With each level-up comes new power-ups or stuff added to the game to help you live longer, and more info about the game.  Although it can be frustrating at times, i highly reccoment this game to anyone who loves racing, suspense and going fast.

												Race The Sun is not a typical "end-less runner" game.  The game is so much more.   Each region you pass through increasingly offers greater challenges.   The soundtrack of the game is amazing, it organically fits with the game.   It offers basically unlimited re-playability.  In my personal opinion the game does not get old,  even after goofing up several times, the game lures you in for more and more to get past that region you messed up on.  The game is very entertaining, you will not be disappointed.  Buy this game!!

Posted: January 28, 2016
												Race The Sun is a simple game that is entertaining to play while you wait for friends to come online. The goal of the game is to fly your craft as far as you can before the sun hits the horizon.It is quite difficult to complete some of the challenges and can take a good amount of hours before you start to benefit from the ship upgrades. Everyday the main maps randomizes.This mechanic helps to make the maps more interesting. This game also has a great Workshop community that provides extra maps for the game.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Fun, challenging and fast. I really like the level editor and the new dlc "sunrise", they allow us to make endless levels with no setting sun. This makes it really relaxing until you hop into the race the sun mode again. Race the sun offers a nice gradual challenge that gets way crazier as you go. Once you get better and further you will start to see the first worlds change.  This is a nice game to enjoy the ost or listen to your own tunes in the background while playing. I'm glad I got this during early access, it just reminds me of a couple games on my commodore and 286.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												The game has a very simple concept: you race the sun. The entire game is you travelling horizontally (primarily, you can use jump powerups for a vertical boost, but you never stop moving forwards) until either the sun goes down or you crash into something. Most of the time, you'll crash. The sun can be "un-set" with booster pickups, encountered as you move forward. But this just prolongs the inevitable. And I know I'm basically repeating the blurb but this is the entire game, quite simply. It's good, but I don't think it's worth £6.99 (or $9.99, I guess). Get it maybe when it's on sale, but I wouldn't buy it full price.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												And awesome high speed game where you take control of an odd plane thing and attempt to glide along this odd land, your plane is solar powered though, so you must collect powerups that cause the sun to go higher into the sky, but in return this makes obstacles come at you faster. This game originated on kongregate, the flash website, and have evolved into easily one of my all time favorite games. With decals, powerups, passive abilities, a workshop, and the infuriating apocolypse mode. And much much more i'd say this game, although slightly overpriced for its content is quite a nice game pick up when its on sale. It also has a "zen" mode DLC I plan on purchasing this mode when I can.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Race the sun is the kind of game you are more likely to play when you end up having some free time to kill.Understand here : When you are waiting for the turkey you put in the oven to be ready.It's fairly easy to play, a bit harder to master, addictive and frustrating.- Easy to play : Indeed, you just have to doge some "super-structure", grab some "power-up", not let the sun set.- Hard to master : Reaching zone 10 is hard, so is surviving apocalypse mode.- Addictive and frustrating : Typical of the classical "Die and Retry". You will try over and over until you reach your "achievements".But the most frustrating part isn't about dying few points away from the 1M ... It's about letting the turkey in the oven for too long.

Posted: August 2, 2015
												I'll give it a thumbs up.  This is a simpler game, but I think that's what makes it good.  It does what it does well, giving you a small plane you have to charge across the landscape while avoiding obsticles and trying to go as far as you can before the sunlight runs out.  Some of the task might need some fine tuning, but it's something you can do a few runs on when you have half an hour and aren't someone that plays solitare.

Posted: July 31, 2015

												This is a great game, ladies and gents. Welcome to the race against time and the sun. Hop into your trusty, solar-powered, plane, Penelope (you can name your plane whatever you want), and dodge, weave and bob your way through a trippy block universe. Collect powerups that stop the sun from setting, jumps and shields. As  you level up there are lots of sweet unlockables you can attach to your ship to make gameplay more interesting. Blast through portals into unknown universes where the laws of physics do not apply. Hit ramps, catch major air, do some barrel rolls.Gameplay is challenging and compelling without the need for fancy graphics. Great use of color and sound to set the mood, Lots of homebrew levels in the workshop for endless replayability.Get this game. You need this game.

Posted: July 4, 2015
												It's like F-Zero had a child with... Super Hexagon! Very-fast, twitch-control gameplay, very well crafted procedurally generated levels each day with bizzare presentation and level-music. In essense the game revolves around an abstract mechanic of collecting power ups to rotate the planet and extend the amount of time the sun is shining. Why is this even a thing? Because your ship's solar-powered existence depends on it! Remember that Speed movie with Neo in that sometimes comes on around christmas, where the bus can't fall below 50mph or it blows up? This game is variant of this scenario, only the the ship's speed / power is directly dependent on the amount of sunshine available. As soon as the sun starts to set, you're presented with a pinch-style music arrangement that echos the danger you're faced with. Your ship gradually starts to slow down as less and less power becomes available to it from the sunlight. Desperately swerving around crazy moving cubes and obstacles like a level from mario 64 put on a motorway, you're looking for sunlight orbs to extend the day, but ultimately it's futile, as like the music, the levels never end! You're doomed to blow up at some point (provided you're human and need to sleep or die in the future)The Steam version also benefits from having a pretty nifty level-editor and user created content, if that's your kindof thing. I primarily played this game on the PS4 before owning it on Steam however.Like fast racing games, thrill of impact when a mistake is made? the challenge of having to start from the beginning and survive the whole onslaught you just faced just to reveal the mysery of what's encountered round the corner on the next level, like the good old 8 and 16-bit days? This is a game you'll enjoy, and even if you don't you'll have a laugh anyway.

Posted: August 9, 2015
Summary'Race The Sun' is a nice, casual game that is soley based on your reaction time and ability to contemplate potential obstacles. With several pickups along the way such as jumping and extending the timer - essentially the Sun - it makes for a very fast paced yet simple game that makes it such great fun to play. You are able to edit levels, download from Steam Workshop, conquer a vast majority of levels, jump through 'World Portals', gain buffs, alter your ship. In ddition, it is a  beautifully attractive and the mechanics are simple enough to enjoy. It has my recommendation!How does the game work?When entering a level, you are placed outside of a house - a small introduction with nothing but a very simplistic washed out house with the level's name and a small quote underneath that varies from time to time. After a couple of seconds, your ship whizzes in and off you go, fighting against the creeping dark as the Sun declines above the horizon. The objective is to avoid the darkness and to reach the sun as quickly as possible. You are flying a solar ship that is, well... Powered by sunlight. The less time you spend in the Sun, the slower you become until you eventually stop all together.As you stay in the Sun, you progress through the level: dodging and weaving between obstacles: from various towers to small, cube-like blockades. Some of these assets move, some don't. As the levels progress, it becomes more difficult to keep up with the Sun as it becomes darker and darker.The game mechanics are relatively straight forward, making it one of those games were you try to race to the end of the level in an attempt to beat a timer.Powerups?Yup. Powerups. At just under an hour of gameplay time (not much I know) I have managed to unlock two types of powerups: one extends the Sun's time in the sky, thus speeding up your ship and another that allows you to elevate to a reasonable height so you may fly over the obstacles. Both of these have saved - and crushed - my ship all together.The MusicIn games like this, music is important: ranging from a dramatic score to a rather soothing tone depending on what lies ahead. The music in 'Race The Sun' is quite upbeat and dramatic. I enjoy the change per level and the transition between regions. Very nice indeed.ConclusionDefinitely recommended. The game is fun, addicting and fast-paced - enough to keep yourself entertained. A really awesome game. 'Race The Sun' is one of the nichés in the game industry for sure.

												Smooth, fluid, intuitive first-person POV endless runner. Stark, barren landscape and vaguely Middle Eastern-flavored music give it a desert-at-sunset vibe, like Lawrence of Arabia on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rocket sled. Whip-quick turnaround at death coupled with a wide variety of challenges and map layouts to spatter with your burnt, twisted wreckage makes the game feel almost no-stakes. Smashing headlong into a wall and exploding has never been so relaxing.

Posted: August 9, 2015
												Great game.It's a very simple, fast-paced game that can cater to all skill levels.On the earlier sections, it isn't a difficult game. However, as you improve at the game (how much you improve can sometimes sneak up on you) you begin reaching the later areas, which can quickly descend into a chaotic mess which can be very difficult to traverse. The difficulty ramps up to you.Then you have the interesting mechanic of the sun. As the sun sets, the shadows grow, which makes the game more difficult as shadows slow you down, making the sun set faster. This is a mechanic I find fun and cool, as it gives you more incentive to try and keep the sun up and adds a little extra urgency.This game can really make you panic when you have a good run and the sun reaches the horizon. Which I feel is great.All-in-all, it's a great game that I recommend playing.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												It's hard to find reasons for this game not being awesome. Race The Sun provides a simple concept and goal for the player: dodge obstacles, stay out of the shadows, grab power-ups and score pickups. It's really that easy and therefore a very accessible game. Race The Sun's core mechanic, your vehicle being sun-powered, adds a unique factor of experience. Combine that with the insane speed at which you fly, and you'll have one exhilarating experience. Race The Sun is a perfect game for playing on a daily basis and due to level scrambling every day, the game greatly succeeds at variation. And then I haven't mentioned the very easy-to-use level editor yet. Too easy? Try apocalypse mode. This game just works in so many ways, and can really excite you on a daily basis. I therefore recommend this to everyone who likes a bit of fast-paced excitement with smooth graphics and strong mechanics.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												I played it a lot before I actually binded it to steam, I remember buying it on release.  I actually forgot I had it on steam, so the reviews a little belated.Now, if you're looking for graphically-intensive game, this is not your game, what this is however it a very fast-paced, relaxing, and nerve-wrecking game. Relaxing and nerve-wrecking? But how you may ask? Simple, while the gameplay and atmosphere is smooth, the tight controls and near-misses you will crave are addicting, the music is calm, but the impending doom holds a sense of mortality, it's a game like no other. If you wanted a comparison, then the closest I can think of is Burnout: Takedown 3, at the very least adrenaline is the same, while the graphic tend to reminescent of Star Fox.Be aware the game is pretty naked, there is no story, no plot, no real objectives, it is just you, the desolate island filled with obstacles and numerous contraptions, and your meager attempt at survival in this barren world, if the term melancholy resonates with you, this game just might be for you.

Posted: October 26, 2015
												Since the aesthetics and gameplay can be summed up rather handily in any of the videos above, I'll just comment on what you can't see: the controls. I'm hardly a video game savant so when I feel like a game is needlessly wasting my time with artifical difficulty, I'm out pretty quickly. Race the Sun however never feels like it's cheating; there's a clear weight and momentum to your movement that's easy to grasp, which means the blame for my many, many (many) premature deaths lie squarely on my own fossilized refelexes. Combined with a goal-based upgrade system and constantly changing maps, I regularly find myself picking it up and sinking in 10-15 minutes whenever I need a break from a bigger title. An easy reccomendation!

Posted: July 30, 2015
Notice: I got this game for free, so that may or may not bias my opinion. You have been warned.Race the sun is a sort of "Surfing" game in which you play as a solar powered aircraft (that doesn't have a slowdown function or landing gear, because video games) which is trying to keep itself from crashing by chasing the sun.This game goes easy on you at first, then they'll add gameplay components overtime, with pickups, equipment, and more.One draw to this game is that you can make your own levels, publish them, and play others' creations via the Steam Workshop.Likes: The gameplay is fast-paced, always keeping you on your toes. The style of the game is futuristic, minimal, and polygonal, all of which are popular. Full Gamepad support, along with simple controls, could let you play this game with a Atart 2600 Joystick. Seriously. This is an example of a successful Kickstarter campaign, showing that crowdfunding can work. Every day, the maps reset, making sure you don't play the exact same map everyday.Dislikes: ZER0 Multiplayer. (would've been great for couch gaming.) This game feels like something to be played on the go, so I'd suggest the mobile version. Too many attempts failed, and you could potentially rage quit. On the topic of User-created maps, Your Mileage May Vary.(seriously, this game is begging for a Star Fox skin.)

Posted: July 31, 2015
												I have to reccomend this game with an astounding amount of praise, in this game I found myself engrossed in the music and it started off slow, but then I started u8nlocking things, memorizing my world that was generated and learned new tricks, such as using pyramids to actually gain air in vital moments to jump blocks and gain enough height to avoid death on many occasions but what stood out to me the most was this progressive feeling of what felt like an artistic representation of man itself, it started out peaceful and with nothing but cubes and pyramids but then before I knew it, there were tunnels formed and then moving blocks then windmills and then full on structures that changed how I had to manuever differently then moving circles that seemed to move just to try to kill me, then bombs. Bombs that blinded me and acted as a wonderful but frustrating obstacles, all this time everything was getting faster and faster until I was sandwiched between two rows of cubes and then darkness, I was shifting in my seat and hoping my battery didn't die, then I saw a wall and nearly cried, 100K points in, next thing you know it lifted and I felt so relieved. This was all in a single sitting; I can't reccommend this game enough, especially because the portals add a new dynamic which put me into a cardgame from hell, dodging aces, spades, clubs and hearts. It was tense and marvelous as I was collecting points and taking in the hellish sight constantly asking what the ♥♥♥♥ was going on... I'm definitely going to play this game for much longer.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												The game has a very simple concept: you race the sun. The entire game is you travelling horizontally (primarily, you can use jump powerups for a vertical boost, but you never stop moving forwards) until either the sun goes down or you crash into something. Most of the time, you'll crash. The sun can be "un-set" with booster pickups, encountered as you move forward. But this just prolongs the inevitable. And I know I'm basically repeating the blurb but this is the entire game, quite simply. It's good, but I don't think it's worth £6.99 (or $9.99, I guess). Get it maybe when it's on sale, but I wouldn't buy it full price.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												So, a racing game. Race The Sun (Flippfly﻿) has an interesting mechanic, whereby your solar-powered vehicle will slow down if it's in the shade, and you can only go so far—period—because the sun is setting. It uses a progression mechanic based on completing various objectives (collecting power-ups, getting your score multiplier to a particular level, making it through stages without any collisions, etc.), and since you have 3 different objectives available at any time, there's usually SOMETHING you can make progress on……until you can't, because you're terrible at racing games and your reflexes just can't make the cut (and by "you're", I really mean "I'm"). I guess this is what I get for not playing any racing games since F-Zero﻿ on the SNES (1991) and Mario Kart 64﻿ on the N64 (1997).

												"Just one more try!"I got this for free, in some promotion on Steam. Strange, as it has cards, but I don't look a gift horse in the mouth. :) As with all the games that drop cards, I at least look at it while it's running anyway to get the drops. Sailing around, trying to evade obstacles. [crash] Ok, try again. Sailed a bit longer. [crash] ... Smiling, and startled by every crash, I had fun and got the "Just one more attampt!" bug until I had other things to do.The map changes every day, which is very nice indeed (I can imagine it would get repetitive if it were ever the same level to start on).Definitely going to go back to this. Random side-note: I can't play actual first/third person perspective, I get dizzy-sick. Here it's just steering left and right, perhaps catching a jump of different kinds (as far as I've seen yet), but you still head straight for the sun. This actually works for me. Wheee!

You are a spacecraft that runs on sunlight, and you must collect certain items to keep up with the sun without getting lost in the dark or crashing into one of the many various obsticles. Great soundtrack, tons of fun, and an overall interesting little indie runner game.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												Ten dollars? Eh, I've seen less substantial things sell for a lot more. Still, I got it for five--- I suggest you do the same.Pricing aside, this game is excellent. Rudamentary on the surface, but extraordinarilly atmospheric. The musical score, while also simple, draws you into this little fantasy: you'll feel like you're in a different world while your brain tightens as you pass through every corridor, through every rolling block. The concept of the game is intriguing as you are literally chasing the setting sun, getting powerups to stay in the light that keeps your ship powered, breathing a legitimate sense of adventure into the experience.It's a great challenge game to play a few rounds with your friends and try to break each other's records.If you're into fast-moving arcadish games, throw this one on your wishlist and wait for a sale.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Playing Race the Sun is an experience in playing the pure essence of racing games, and it’s tremendously rewarding. The gameplay is simple, the graphics are minimalist (and beautiful, I might add, in their simplicity), and the controls are remarkably smooth.The developer also regularly changes the world you race in so it doesn’t become about just rote memorization, but you have enough time to figure out each world before it’s reset. There’s even an upgrade system which allows you to swap out accessories to change how you race – but even that is satisfyingly minimalist.And to top it all off, it’s integrated with Steam Workshop, allowing you to access hundreds of player-made maps for an even more unique experience.Everyone has those games they like to play when they just need a minute to relax or if they don’t have much time to devote to a game, and I’m happy to add Race the Sun to my list. At the same time, it’s robust enough to drawn you in for extended play sessions, with a relaxing cadence married to high-stakes urgency.It's a great little game.Full review.[www.thesewall.com]

Posted: August 19, 2015
												Race The Sun is a game where every aspect of your experience will be pointing out to "perfection". It's difficult to describe my thoughts on it, and I also don't think it's necessary. This is a MUST OWN, it's really that simple. And then complexity comes, when you try to describe it. Let's start with the obvious.You have your solar powered craft, the setting sun in the background and obstacles in front of you. When you complete a set of obstacles, you arrive at a new region, which will certainly be far more cruel and unforgiving that the previous. You have a variety of power- ups, the yellow beacon thingy is the most important one, since, and this is where the "race the sun" part comes, the sun, as I said, is setting and your craft is solar powered. The yellow power- up will speed you up, prolonging your pathetic death, just long enough to see yourself plunge into an obstacle at an utterly insane speed, all because of your suddenly malfunctioning reflexes. But that's OK, you could always momrize the terrain and each obstacle, right? Nope. The people that made the game are actually so cool, that they are changing the game World every 24 hours. It may be similar to the World from yesterday, but it may be completely different. There is also a Portal World, which is also different every day. It may be a relaxing one, like, for example, observing a space battle. Or it may be one of those Portal Worlds that keep you on the edge of your seat, praying for a successful exit.They recently added a labyrinth mode, which is very fun to play and will really test your reflexes. The Sunrise DLC is absolutely worth buying.In conclusion, you have a perfect gameplay, a real challenge, amazing soundtrack, new World every 24 hours, Leaderboards, ship customization and a loss of words, upon witnessing perfection.

Posted: August 12, 2015
												This is a beautifully unique and abstract take on a Temple Run style of games. Even though the soundtrack can be relaxing at times, you'll always be on the edge of your seat, doing everything you can to keep those last moments of light and life from slipping away before you fall to the bottom of the leaderboards. I HIGHLY recommend playing this game, but you will die. That is not a maybe, you WILL die. A LOT.Even though this is a wonderful game to look at and listen to, I wouldn't suggest playing it if you rage easily. It's not hard to lose your sense of depth perception and slip too far to the left, ultimately causing your ship to blow up. But it's not too hard to keep your hand steady and get yourself to the end of each reigon before recieving your reward. Even if you die, you're rewarded for playing. Multiple ship upgrades, level add-ons, etc. There's so much more to this game than meets-the-eye. Don't think so? Spend the measly $10 and find out yourself. It's an experience worth experiencing. ;3

Posted: August 5, 2015
												So. I fell in love with the game forever ago but never got a chance to snag it until the free day, boy am I glad someone told me about it being free. I've wanted to play a ' Jet Slalom' type game that was actually decent for a while since I've played  one when I was little and this really hit the nail on the head. First of all, the slow start of the game was nice, the way the in-game goals progress and actually reward you slowly was wonderful. Every level or so you'd unlock something else, Tris, Jumpers, Boosters, Warps, and then the Shield/Escape warp, not quite in that order though. The challenges were imposing at first, but as you got used to how things controlled or got a new kind of power things got easier, like now I can consistently hit Region 6 no problem.  Another thing I most enjoyed was the fact that just when you start to relax and get into a groove (because up until region 8, things were kind of the same here and there. Go <left for more Tris instead of right> at so+so structure, even if the map is changed daily. I hit region 9 and suddenly had structures I had never seen before appear, every few regions is like that really.So many things in this game amaze me every time I boot it up, the little warp zones to go to other worlds (Created by players I suppose) and the extra game modes keep things refreshing and wonderful. The Sunrise DLC keeps things calming, the unlockable Apocalypse mode and Labyrinthia make the game even more challenging and new, especially the latter.My only complaints would be that you can't change to a different kind of vehicle for aesthetic reasons and the issue that rarely the Tri's won't pick up for you.10/10 would play again and die, then play and die again, and again.

Posted: August 5, 2015
												Like many, I aquired this game for free via a one-day sale.  However, now that I've played it a bit, I think it's worth the price.  It's actually been quite addictive, despite that fact that I'm not usually into this kind of game.The game is a simple one, so far with a whole 3 buttons to use lol.  You fly a fast moving aircraft along the ground, using the arrow keys to move left and right.  If you pick up a jump power-up, you can hit space to jump over an impending obstacle.  If anything hits your wings, you get bounced around and lose part of your point multiplier.  If you direct hit something, and this is usually what happens, you die.  You also die if you're in darkness too long, which usually happens at sunset.  Hitting boosters will reverse time, allowing you more time before the sun sets.  Ultimately, you will die.  A lot.The music and atmosphere make for a fantastic experience, and the game tends to make fun of the constant deaths.  It's expected that you will die, it's just a matter of how long.  There are always three objectives to complete, and finishing any of them will reward you with points towards leveling up.  Leveling up in turn awards anything from new power-ups, to upgrades to your aircraft, to things like new play mods and new decals.  Any objectives you finish are replaced with new ones, seemingly selected at random.  Some are easy, like collecting X number of points across any number of runs (which simply keeping trying will eventually earn).  Others can be brutal, like going several regions in a row while only turning left.  Ultimately, though, it keeps the game fresh for longer.Eventually, unless you are into high scores, the game will likely run out of anything for anyone to do.  The graphics, while rather atmospheric, are admittely simple polygons.  It is, after all, and indie game.  In the end, I'd say this is a decent game at a fair price.
